Ein schönes schauriges Spiel für die Nacht zu Neujahr. Es wird einiges an Rätseln und subtilem Horro geboten. Sowohl passend im Artstil als auch in der muskilalischen Untermalung. Außerdem beinhalt das Spiel viel sehr intressantes zum schwedischen Aberglauben&Mythenwesen&Folkore. Es wirkt wirklich als würde gerade eine echte Geschichte erzählt werden. 
Zum Neujahr passt die altertümliche schwedische Tradtion des Year Walk bei dem halluzinierend auf Grund der Dunkelheit im Wald ausgesetzt wird, um seinen Weg hinaus zu finden und dabei einen Sneek Peak auf die Zukunft zu erhalten. 

Mir hat es wirklich sehr gut gefallen, obwohl ich die Story schon aus einem Lets Play kannt.

PS: Sogar einer ängstlichen Person, mit der ich es zusammen gespielt habe, hat das Spiel irgendwann gefesselt, sodass der Horro irgendwann nur noch Nebensache war. :)

38925561.review:
Year Walk is an enticingly atmospheric game. It does a wonderful job of building tension as you're wandering through the woods with the beautiful soundtrack. The puzzles are all satisfyingly challenging (though that does not extend to the achievements; a couple are strangely obtuse for no reason but are at least easy to obtain with a guide). 
Most of all, I appreciate the in-game encyclopedia of the folklore inspiring the game. Read through it as soon as I started up the game, and I felt like it really added to the experience, knowing a bit about the creatures I would run into. Also did a good job of really setting the tone for the game.
The two endings do leave something to be desired, but (for what feels like the first time ever) I wasn't too put off by this. For me, Year Walk was very much about the journey rather than the destination. The story, when we get down to it, is frustratingly heartbreaking. But if you're able to put that aside, it's a great little game.
Ultimately, a short but worthwhile adventure.

38903381.review:
In short, Year Walk is the mobile port of a game you never played (but should), and about folklore you never knew about (but should).

In long, Year Walk is based on the pagan ritual of Årsgång, and the Swedish folklore behind it. In theory, if the participant survived or passed certain tests during the Walk, he would be able to see into the future.
  
Done on nights that were believed to be more magically and spiritually charged than others, such as new years eve, Christmas eve, and solstices, the participant was required to deprive himself of food, rest, and light for a day before making his way through the woods to the nearest churchyard. It was there, if he was deemed worthy enough, he could learn his fate and the fates of others in the year to come.

In the game, you are one such individual, and making your way to the churchyard is your task.

But you are not alone in the woods.

The demons, sprites, and figments of folklore surround you and test you on your journey. They do not wish you well, and they will make you prove your worth in the woods. There are light puzzles you must solve, usually revolving around backtracking and fetching...things...which can get very dull. Fortunately they are short, save one, which I highly recommend using headphones for, otherwise you will more than likely have difficulty. You’ll know it when you get to it. I almost wish this one wasn’t in the game, though the conclusion of it will stick with you for quite some time.

In fact, most of the game will likely stick with you. The spirits of the woods are subtle yet terrifying to the core. The sounds of the woods are quiet and haunting. The color palate is soft, yet foreboding. The in game encyclopedia is a wonderful, and for one of the puzzles, required, read. Or at least a quick scroll through. I won’t spoil for what here, but let’s just say it’s one of the best uses of an in game encyclopedia I have ever seen. Though nobody may say so directly, Year Walk is an often subtle, a few times not so subtle, short, horror adventure.

If you can get past the odd, mobile-friendly navigation of practically strafing through the world instead of walking through it, as well as the aforementioned backtracking, you should definitely play this, especially if it’s on sale. It’s not long at all, a couple hours at most, but very meaty and entertaining for those couple hours. There are incentives to replay, too, through some mysterious achievements. Year Walk will frighten you, scare you at times, and chill you almost constantly. Maybe even frustrate you, or stump you. But yes, you should definitely give it a go.

Why?

Well, I think we all, at one point or another in our lives, have wished we could know some of what our futures hold for us. Though debates could rage at what the idea of seeing the future means to us. Some would want to know it all; some would not want to know anything about what is to come. Some could say the future can be changed; some would say everything is written in stone. Some would say if they knew their future they would try to change it; others would say they would leave it alone, come what may. Year Walk offers a glimpse into a world where such discussions would have merit beyond character studies and musings. Where such a privilege would have to be earned in a dangerous world, in a snowy evening, in a churchyard.

36328302.review:
Fun! Scary! Rich in lore! Beautiful to look at! I enjoyed almost 100% of Year Walk.

Positives:

There is something extremely delicious about a game that encourages you to have a notebook handy to keep track of clues and write down hints. And it's doubly good in a snowy icy world, for the same reasons I love mysteries set in a snowed-in cabin or the remote northern woods in winter. You become the cold but determined detective and the sheer joy of solving clues is enough to pull you forward. Year Walk really delivers on the atmosphere, you can tell it is lovingly crafted with a deep interest in Swedish lore in mind. Maybe because I typically get through games slower than most people, my natural tendency to take my time and enjoy the view helped me become quite immersed in the game. 

The horror of Year Walk is very beautiful, some jump scares but also subtle reveals, eerie atmosphere, and the game likes to mess around with the fourth wall a tiny bit. There are parts that are scary, parts that are sad, and some parts are just lovely to see play out. The sound design helps add to the scariness and is very, very well done. It is all very memorable and you will surely have a favorite moment or two by the end that will stick in your head for a while. The eerie atmosphere never gets old, and I loved that it never relied on gore or violence to frighten me, but well crafted visual cues, dark implications, and building tension. You truly feel you are on the precipice between the real world and some strange spirit world, and there is an increasing sense of dread as you progress that maybe the spirit world really isn't a place for humans, much less one lonely human in the middle of the night on new years eve.

Negatives: 

 The gosh darn singing puzzle really got my knickers in a twist.I would recommend trying this puzzle for a little while to be properly immersed in the game, because being hopelessly lost in the woods with bizarre singing and your life on the line is part of the story, and hell if this puzzle doesn't perfectly put you in that mindset. But just have a guide ready, scribble the solution out on your notebook ahead of time so you have it, because it relies ENTIRELY on your quality of hearing and you will be one step closer to madness with each failed attempt. You might still have to try it a couple times with the guide, even. It's one of the most frustrating puzzles I've run up against in a game.

Other things I didn't like where very minor. For the most part this was a very smooth experience. Every once in a while I got stumped because the next action you take is to click and drag something, and you can tell in these moments this game was made for an iPad. There is one area near the end of the game I was excited to uncover but there was surprisingly little to discover there and we never had a reason to go back to it, at least in the first playthrough (I only played through once), so that was a smidge disappointing. 

In closing:

Year Walk is memorable, well made, and throughly spooky. There are some replayability incentives, though I can imagine it getting a little tedious playing through the game back to back. It will be a game I pick up again once I've forgotten enough of the scares and I'm ready to be frightened alone in the snowy woods again. For anyone who loves horror games it's a must, and even those who typically aren't fond of the genre will find a genuinely interesting narrative and enjoyable game.

Tldr/; Great game. Some minor bumps with one really frustrating puzzle (get a guide for the singing puzzle ahead of time). Take your time, it's beautiful and scary and worth it. Definitely recommended.

Year Walk is an atmospheric puzzle game takes you through a Swedish Phenomena which is the games namesake. While it took me less than 2 hours to complete, I highly recommend this game. I don't fault it for the short amount of gameplay. It tells a sufficiently interesting and thoroughly creepy story, without dragging on for too long. The story (greatly enhanced if you read the encyclopedia entries), environment, and sounds, all come together to create a scary, indie, gem of a game.  I'm classically a wimp with horror games, but I found this to be perfectly on the edge for me. 

Not sure how often this game goes on sale, but I managed to snag it for around $1 during a steam sale a few years back. Would recommend you do the same, play it with the lights out, and let yourself be immersed. Oh, and take my advice and play again once you complete the game. Address what wasn't addressed during your first Year Walk. That'll put the perfect bow on your experience.

I rate this game a perfect 1 spooky Swedish tale out of 0 spooky Swedish tales I knew of beforehand.

35694623.review:
There isn't much positive to say about this game, except for the visuals. The visuals are really beautiful, and sometimes eerie, and will definitely give you a short fix of novelty, if that's something you deeply desire. You will also learn a little bit about Swedish folklore, which to me is unfairly overlooked. It's much cooler than Greek mythology, which seems to be more popular in creative works of art.

But aside from that:
It's very short (1.5 hours on average), the puzzles are meh, it's sometimes unclear how the game mechanics work, the sidescrolling format and simplified interaction mechanics never let you forget that this is in fact a game, so it's hard to get immersed in the experience, and the whole thing feels like some interactive presentation about Swedish folklore.

Get this game if you want to spend an hour looking at some beautiful visuals. If you are looking for a good game, or even an immersive experience, look somewhere else.

35025216.review:
I didn't really enjoy my time with Year Walk, and that's a shame. 

A lot of love clearly went into this game, and if the mechanics were a bit more fleshed out it would be more fun to wander the world over and over again to solve the puzzles (which are obtuse). This isn't a bad thing per-se, but I needed to use the first hint for each part to at least get started, unlike games like Portal, Limbo, Inside, etc where you often can piece together what you need to do using the environment on hand.

To get it out of the way, the art style is GORGEOUS. Moving on.

The story was too sparse for me as well, and conveyed in such disjointed pieces I needed wikipedia to actually explain it. Lastly, calling this a horror game is a bit of a stretch. There's really only one truly unsettling puzzle involving 4 missing items, and less than half a dozen jump scares. I love being scared, but this game could have ditched the jump scares completely and it wouldn't have suffered for it.

If you have an hour to kill and it's on sale for a dollar or two, you might enjoy it more than me, so don't take this as a bash piece... I just didn't feel there was enough there to justify my time.

34942035.review:
[h1]The distinctive Swedish folklore around which [url=store.steampowered.com/app/269050/Year_Walk/]Year Walk[/url] is based is infinitely more interesting than the resulting game.[/h1]

I wandered the woods looking for spirits in seemingly random locations. I noted pagan patterns and reproduced them elsewhere. I read and reenacted obscure Scandinavian legends described in the encyclopedia. I manipulated polygonal floating shapes in the Beyond.

The game's excellent mythological source material is unjustly wasted on flat design and unintuitive mechanics. Despite several promising base ideas, as a whole it just isn't very entertaining.

The first puzzle you encounter, a wooden box with strange symbols arranged in a circular pattern, is one you literally can't solve until after you first complete the game. It acts as a sort of epilogue to reveal the true ending, which is fine except it highlights one of the game's main problems: elements are presented in an order that feels wrong.

Figuring out how to perform simple actions due to awkward controls turns out to be unnecessarily convoluted and my main gripe with the game. Many times I knew what to do (wind the doll, carry an object to the next scene, etc) but failed in the execution. That's not innovation, that's bad UX design.

[h1]Positive[/h1]
[list]
[*] Excellent soundtrack
[*] Unique presentation
[*] Swedish folk tales and original source material
[/list]

[h1]Negative[/h1]
[list]
[*] A handful of cheap jump scares
[*] Completely useless hints
[*] Outlandishly unclear and unresponsive controls
[*] Short, not a lot of interactive content
[*] Generally misguided UX despite effort to port from mobile to PC
[*] Thin narrative involving the actual characters of the story
[/list]

I found the dark, fable-based narritive extemely enjoyable and interesting, thought the visuals, sound and feel were sympathetic and excellent, and found it original in a good way. It's very short and light on puzzles, and a lot of the time I recorded was spent reading the background text. Learning the folklore with the appropriate creepy ambience, is the undoubted highlight and for me the game gave a good platform for this, albeit with a few rough edges.

Puzzles are simplistic, but have a modern "think-outside-the-box" feel, utilising sound or gestures for instance, which does make them more engaging, but there is little narritive logic to any of them and I was left wanting for more signposting at times. There was one puzzle whose solution was quickly obvious but didn't seem to work, prompting a frustrating wild-goose-chase for other solvable puzzles followed by an eventual guide-referral revealing that it was possible, just incredibly awkward using a mouse (due I suspect to inadequate adaptation from a touch-screen original).

Overall a very good experience for me, though a little dear for the entertainment some would get out of it I suspect, depending on their level of interest in the story, and taste for the horror and puzzle elements.

33851281.review:
Year Walk is a dark and mature adventure game based on Swedish folklore. You play as Daniel Svensson, a young man who on the New Year's Eve 1893 decides to undergo the ancient rite of årsgång (i.e. year walk). During your årsgång you encounter various mythical beasts and creatures as you wander around the small village and solve puzzles.

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
The 2D visuals are fairly basic but they are also quite stylish and atmospheric. The mythical creatures are well realized too. Overall the visuals are well done and fit the grim theme extremely well.

[h1]Audio[/h1]
The game has a great moody soundtrack and the sound effecs are well done too. There's no voice acting.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Most of your time in Year Walk will be spent wandering around the map and looking for puzzles to solve to progress the story. The game doesn't give you too many directions and often the puzzles are rather obtuse. On a more positive note the PC version has an extensive hint system, so getting completely stuck is rare.

There's very little dialogue in the game and almost no items to use. The puzzles have some variety at least, although personally I thought they were bit of a hit and miss.

Year Walk also uses a rather curious movement system. While exploring a location you are always facing the same way and can only move sideways. At specific spots you can follow a path up or down and move to a different area. This system is slightly confusing at first, but on a positive note the game does feature a solid map system.

[h1]Difficulty[/h1]
While the puzzles are not terribly complex, many of them are rather obtuse and it's fairly easy to get stuck for a while. 

[h1]Controls[/h1]
Year Walk was originally made for iOS and it certainly shows to some extent. The controls are passable enough with mouse and keyboard too, but some actions are slightly tricky to perform.

[h1]Story and Writing[/h1]
Much of the game is based on research by Swedish folklore expert Theodor Almsten and it certainly shows. The setting and the characters feel authentic and overall the writing is very solid.

The narrative itself is quite interesting too, although I would have liked to see more of the story told in the game itself instead of the encyclopedia and the journal.

Without spoiling too much the game also has two separate endings. Finishing the game the first time around will give you some hints that will help you reach a second alternate ending. It's by no means a happy ending, but in many ways it's a more satisfying one.

[h1]Bugs and Glitches[/h1]
I didn't encounter any major bugs and overall the game was quite polished.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
Overall I found Year Walk a pretty solid adventure game. It is extremely atmospheric and the story is quite interesting too. Unfortunately the gameplay isn't particularly interesting and the puzzles can be bit too obtuse. Still, I would recommend the game, especially if you are interested in ancient folklore.

It took me 1.5 hours to reach both the endings.

Красивая, мрачная, местами щекочущая нервы игра, в которой есть и интересный сюжет, основанный на шведских преданиях, и приятная рисовка, и прекрасный саундтрек.
В центре сюжета, как и указано в описании, лежит шведское фольклорное гадание "Årsgång" ("Годовая прогулка"), которое заключается в том, что доброволец, отважившийся ступить на этот путь, в канун рождества отказывается от пищи и воды, домашнего уюта и близких, запирается в темной комнате и ждет наступления ночи. В полночь путник направляется к церкви, преодолевая темные леса, полные мрачных мистических созданий. Если "ходоку" удается следовать всем инструкциям и решать загадки, встающие на пути, он добирается до церкви живым, тогда ему являются видения будущего, события, которые будут ждать в новом году.
Мне, как любителю фольклорной и языческой тематики, а также эстету, стилистика игры безумно понравилась. Загадки особо сложными не были, но меня это не расстраивает, потому что процессом я насладилась уж точно. Прошла 2 раза, получила истинную концовку. Пройду ещё разок в канун нового года, чтобы получить оставшиеся 2 ачивки.
Мало сейчас годных игр, эта просто как бальзам на душу, жаль что такая короткая.

33184497.review:
Sure, I know some stuff about the Scandinavian Folklore. Just ask me. I've watched Moomins when I was young, you can't scare me that easy. I know what to expect and I expect a lot of snow, some weird creatures hidden in the darkness and the flickering lights in the distance. So, a year walk? Sign me in.

First of all, you go into a forest, a creepy one, expecting to find an answer you were seeking for so long. A Year Walk is nothing more or less but a complex, eerie adventure which uses no cheap horror elements to scare you. You will feel insecure anyway because of the overall atmosphere and music emerging from all the characters and the places you will encounter. And then, when you start solving the puzzles you will uncover the truth, meeting more and more strange beings taken directly from the folklore. Thanks to the encyclopedia provided you can learn more about them.
So, you expect a big reveal, a true horror at the end, going there tirelessly, only to be left with more answers and a chill down your spine. 

You will travel a lot, but the map is a great asset, marking all the important spots, allowing to find more information. Traveling from a place to place you solve simple puzzles and receive just some basic hints (and you can get more of them on demand if you are stuck). At some point, you will also get an opportunity to unblock some additional features, a journal, and a hidden ending. So, yes, there's a replay value, but as you know the solution to most of the riddles you can complete the plot faster every time (and there's an achievement for that). Your dedication is always rewarded.

The visuals are the strongest part of the Year Walk, creating a great atmosphere, which allows you to experience the game fully. It's a short, yet nice game for a long winter evening. After all, when else would it be relevant...

My final rating? - 8/10

+ The overall atmosphere of the game.
+ The well captured beauty of a Scandinavian folklore.
+ All the lore provided by the developers.
+ A mix of both horror and an adventure game.

- Some puzzles might be too complex (but there are hints provided by the game!), requiring taking some additional personal notes.
- The controls might be annoying at first.

33167203.review:
First played this game on mobile back when it initially came out. While the graphics and gameplay are identical on the PC version, some of the puzzles have been tweaked and lengthened to cater to the new platform. The PC version also edges out a bit in that the experience is not divided across multiple apps, and it comes with some helpful additional features such as a map and a hint system which make the game much less frustrating than it used to be.
As for the game itself, it is still weaker from a gameplay and narrative standpoint than the developer's mobile-exclusive follow-up, Device 6, but it has some really lovely graphics, great ambient sound design, and a unique and quirky endgame that does some fun things with genre. While the game is not the survival horror it sometimes gets marketed as being (it's really a mostly harmless Myst-esque point-and-click), it does have a fantastic atmosphere of dread and isolation and the occassional clever, well-earned jumpscare. 
It's sharp and challenging, but also has a fun, intuitive design that makes it accesible for "casual" gamers.

33044335.review:
I struggle to articulate what it is about this game that left such an impact on me, but I couldn't let Year Walk go without giving it my recommendation.

I've always enjoyed subtle horror elements in video games, but never been a fan of pure horror games for mostly one reason. The jumpscare as of recent in horror has become what autotune is in the modern music industry. A tool for an artist to improve their art, not a means to cover up a lack of talent by littering one's creation with it, and Year Walk does a great job of using this tool alongside it's many others to craft a uniquely unsettling experience.

Horror as a genre in gaming is something that can be hard to keep consistently impartial. When a player only ever sees other characters as something to be scared of, the fear becomes one-dimensional very quickly as almost everything that moves is an obvious threat to the player. I've dropped horror games before because i'm sick of being pulled along while the game rapid fire tries to scare me with loud noises and flashing imagery. However the eerie creepiness of Year Walk just comes naturally as it's often unclear when and if the player should be scared. Between the light safety and the dark horror lies a gray area that Year Walk hides itself amoung: fear of the unknown.

The in game encyclopedia, should the player chose to read it, gives information about the act of Year Walking as well as the five supernatural creatures asociated with it who are all said to pose a threat psyically, mentally, and spiritually. This, alongside all beasts being associated with death or murder in some way immediately sets the expectation for them to be the enemies, or the "scary" part, of this horror game. However there is no terror in the bang, only in the anticipation of it, and the entire buildup for said bang is done inside the player's head. This also creates a sharp contrast with the rest of the game, as the player is put on edge, yet the snowy landscape and ambiance is eerily peaceful.

Year Walk is a puzzle game that is a compelling narrative first, and also just so happens to be scary because of the expectation that the game influenced me to create for myself by making me come face to face with the unknown and entrusting it to continue. This game is horror done so so right, and it's a shame it almost went under my radar, don't let the same happen to you. It's an experience I wish more could experience so that we could stop giving attention to the shit that Youtubers play for reactions.

10/10 Redefined my standards for horror games.

It's a world that bends reality and creates a series of paradoxes. Absolutely enchanting and has been consuming my past several days. I highly recommend playing! It's worth the time.

32268843.review:
[h1]Honest Game Review[/h1]
    As noted by the amount of time I've spent on this game, I think it's pretty obvious thatI enjoyed it. As everyone agrees with, including negative reviews, the art style of this game is astounding as well as the inclusion of Nordic folklore.
    
    Not only is this game based off of folklore, but it even includes an in-game encyclopedia. Another thing I admire about the ue of these subjects, is the creatures and practices in this game are not really well known. The Year Walk itself has been lost through the decades and the developers resurrected the experience using this game. Not only does the encyclopedia bring real world aspects into the game, but the hidden journal at the end as well. I was stunned at the way the game almost turned into an ARG (Alternate Reality Game). 
    [spoiler] At the end of the game, you must walk again. If you remeber the "puzzle box" in the forest, then you'll rewally appreciate the journals. The creator of the game implemented himself into the game, almost as if your own experience is a rendition of his own. I won't spoil anymore for those who want to check it out, but I really think it's worth doing so. [/spoiler]
    Many of the negative comments talk about the puzzles themselves and the need for a walkthrough or the short length of the game, but I think that's what makes this game even more alluring. During year walks, the walker has little to no idea what to expect. We're just thrown into the game and are left to firgure things out for ourselves. This could end up being quite frustrating, but it also adds to realism. At first glance, the game does seem rather short, but if you are up for some exploring and reading some lore, this game could take hours.
    Over all I think this game was definetly worth playing more than once. The art style was amazing, there were some scary aspects, and intriguing backstories. The combination of a game and ARG was something I've never seen before and the journals gave off an uneasy feeling which was very enjoyable. The storyline wasn't uprfront which forces you to immerse yourself into the game. I'll give it a 9/10 only because of the length.

31871350.review:
[i]Quand je disais que j'aimais pas les chevaux...[/i]

[b]Year Walk[/b], sorti en 2014, est un jeu d'ambiance/horreur indépendant parlant du "Year Walk", une coutume scandinave, dans un environnement sombre et lugubre.

[h1]Les plus :[/h1]

- Les graphismes bicolores (noir/blanc) très réussi.
- Pas mal d'informations concernant cette coutume dans l'encyclopédie fournie par le jeu, qui est très intéressante.
- Le jeu fait un peu peur, avec de rares screams mais jouant surtout avec la tension du joueur.
- Les énigmes ne sont pas bloquantes. Si vous êtes bloqués, vous pouvez utiliser les indices, qui vous donneront la solution si vous bloquez vraiment.
- Une super bande-son !
- Une carte relativement grande à explorer, avec ses petits secrets.

[h1]Les moins :[/h1]

- Le jeu est seulement en anglais, donc pour comprendre les textes, le non-initié à la langue anglaise sera paumé. Cependant, ça ne bloque pas la progression dans le jeu. Mais vous perdez l'essentiel.
- Une durée de vie assez courte, entre 30min et 2h de jeu, qui varie en fonction de si vous galérez dans les énigmes, et l'exploration du jeu (si vous cherchez dans tous les recoins, etc...).

[h1]Conclusion :[/h1]

[b]Year Walk[/b] est un bon jeu, nous permettant de découvrir une nouvelle coutume, une nouvelle culture pour certains, tout en mêlant le ludique et l'horreur. A prendre en solde au vu de la durée de vie minuscule.

_ _ _ _

[h1]Si vous avez trouvé cette évaluation utile, et que vous voulez en discuter autour d'un verre, venez rejoindre notre [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/AlternaTyff#curation]page de curation et nos forums ![/url][/h1]

31125837.review:
[h1]Overview[/h1]
Originally released as a mobile app in 2013, Year Walk is a short puzzle horror game developed by Simogo involving the journey of a young man experiencing the act of, well, yearwalking. The player will learn about the various Swedish folklore as they traverse through the winter landscapes and try to glance into what would become of the future. 

[h1]Review[/h1]
[b]Visuals:[/b] Let's begin with the graphics. The art style is designed around geometric shapes and straight lines, being quite well polished and creating a unique artstyle and brings the atmosphere of this game to life. The colors used in the game consists mainly of black and white, which is greatly compliments the aesthetic tone of the setting. At the end of the game, the artist includes a section where the artstyle is very geometric and focuses on the simplicity of shapes, of which I thought was very interesting choice for the finale. Overall, the graphics are very pleasing to look at and crafted thoroughly. 

Rating: A

[b]Music/Sound:[/b] As a horror game, Year Walk provides its fair share of suspensful sound effects that fits well into the player's experience. The jingles that play after completing certain puzzles are also quite rewarding and a nice touch added into the game. The soundtrack is composed by Daniel Olsén, in which he sets in an amazingly atmospheric mood with each of his tracks, based upon the instruments found in Swedish folk music. Definitely one of my favorites in video games and one I find myself returning to. 

Rating: A

[b]Story:[/b] The story of Year Walk is quite simple and easy to follow, although there is definitely a twist in the end that I choose not to spoil for those who still have not played the game yet. A young man wants to gaze into the future, in which he decides to perform an ancient ritual in upon Nordic history, known as the yearwalking. The game goes in depth upon yearwalking as you progress with the game, but I find it rather fascinating along with the rest of the Swedish mythologies that the developers have implemented into the game, each with their own overviews. There's really not much to complain, as the story keeps you emmersed into the very end.

Rating: A

[b]Gameplay:[/b] As a puzzle game, Year Walk provides a display of interesting puzzles that utilies many varieties of techniques. The player will have to be both observant and think outside the box for each one, and they definitely provide a new challenge each one you stumble upon. It flows quite well and weaves into the story, both complimenting each other through, holding up the atmosphere of mystery along with horror. The creativity that are used within the puzzles are probably my favorite aspect of this entire game, and is a wonder to play through.

Rating: A

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
Year Walk shines through all of the aspects of an enjoyable game and brings it to a new level. Its uniqueness and lore-filled gameplay will have the player interested in finding out more about its Nordic origins. The twist ending provides the player with an even stronger sense of determination to truely find out about what the yearwalking is all about. I suppose the only complaint would be that this game is definitely on the short side, which is both a positive and a negative attribute, depending on how you look at it. 

Final Rating: A

30622507.review:
First things first: I counted three horror elements in the game, and they were all jump scares. So, if you're avoiding this because you're concerned about the horror tag, please don't let it deter you. I find myself paralyzed in most horror games, but I never felt that way with Year Walk. 

I love point-and-click adventures, but I particularly enjoyed this game because the mythology behind the plot and mechanics wasn't just dressing. If you want to solve puzzles, you read the encyclopedia. And not in the Witcher-sense of the idea: you don't read it to automatically unlock something else. You have to find things, and the encyclopedia entries help with that.

I also loved the art. As I said, I'm not big on horror games, but I love it nearly every where else. The surreal style mixes with muted colors to create an eerie atmosphere for the game. (Man, I adored that damn horse.) The puzzles serve the atmosphere, as well. They're each their own representation of the creature you're working with (or challenging, depending on your interpretation, I guess). They don't require intense brain power, firing off all of your neurons or anything, but I found them sufficiently challenging and appropriate for what the game is. 

My biggest issue was with the movement. You can't turn around or look to the side, but you move as if you should be able to do those things. But the map is so small it didn't end up as frustrating as I thought it would be.

I'm not sure Year Walk is for everyone, but I'd say it's a must if you enjoy atmospheric and/or point-and-click adventure games.

29470273.review:
Experience the strange, terrifying and alluring folkloric tradition of Year Walking through this short, stylized game. Follow a young mans journey through the Swedish wilderness to see his future, and maybe even change it. Solve puzzles, learn about the dark past of this land, and discover the fables which still wander these woods. Year Walk is a very short experience with little to no replayability but a beautiful soundtrack, compelling art direction and a very very unique story. Originally for the phone/tablet, this game is clearly meant to be played with a touch screen, but is still enjoyable on home computer. 

Pros: Without a doubt this games art is stunning and is what drew this reviewer in at first glance. As well, the music is quite enjoyable, and both music and art in tandem serve to make this game all the more creepy and mysterious. The puzzles in this game are fairly simple, but tough enough to give most pause. Nothing too difficult to be found here, probably a good game for those interested in puzzle based games but new to the style. As well, Year Walk has a very dark theme and deep story for those willing to dig a little bit. To get the full experience from this game you will need to be a gamer who enjoys the story just as much, if not more than, the gameplay. Year Walk is a point and click game, and that should tell you how much real action is to be found in this title. Luckily, Year Walk provides more than enough lore in its story to make it worth a run through or two. The addition of a lore book on the many creatures you’ll meet in this game is a wonderful addition. Gamers with a passion for folk lore will find this game a fantastic lesson in Swedish lore and a wonderful experience.

Cons: As others have stated, this phone game is very short. For many this may cause pause and you may want to wait for a sale before picking this particular title up. It took this reviewer around four hours to completely 100% this title, including all achievements. As well, because Year Walk was originally a phone game it does play a little strangely with a mouse and keyboard. Finally, as a point and click puzzle game there is very little “action”. For those looking for a long lasting, difficult, action fueled experience you are going to be deeply disappointed. 

Overall, Year Walk falls flat in action, and length. However, it does pack a lot into the short hour long experience. The music and art unsettle as this very adult themed tale unravels before you. The lore and backstory are deeply interesting to those who like this sort of tale. The puzzles are soft but deep enough to cause pause and provide a satisfaction once completed. This game is definitely a niche title and will not be enjoyed by most. If you are someone looking for a short experience, enjoy puzzles, and like learning about lore and fantastical creatures, then Year Walk is the game for you. For what it is, I have to recommend it, but please keep in mind the short length and lack of real gameplay in this title. This is more of an experience than a game in most ways.

My only criticism was that it was rather short. I was expecting a longer game but the experience was still a good one!

29282569.review:
[h1]"Year walking? I hope you are joking!"[/h1]
[b]Stina Nilsson[/b]
__________________________________________ 

[h1]Introduction[/h1]

Personally I have no clue about swedish folklore or mythology and grabbed the title simply because it looked kind of unique: setting and visuals seemed to be fresh and interesting and I expected a nice little title that I can play on my tablet and relax along the way.  (Okay, did I seriously miss the "Horror“ tag on the storepage?)

Oh man was I wrong.

However, I have to say that I regret nothing - the game’s fantastic but for scary people probably not the best thing to play at 1 a.m..
__________________________________________ 

[h1]Year walking…[/h1]

The story of the game is mysterious, kind of creepy and mature. At the beginning you are greeted with a short introduction and some small dialogue before starting your 'Year Walk' in attempt to unravel the mysteries of the future. 

On your journey you will encounter several beings of swedish folklore, creepy places and many puzzles and secrets.
The game is a mixture of 2D- and 3D-Textures, you play in first person view, travelling from left to right through different parts of the forest, but at some spots you are able to go up or down to change the location. 

The forest consists of different areas and you will need to backtrack a lot (or you make notes along the way) to find the solution to some riddles and gadgets. These puzzles are quite interesting but nothing new or unique in the genre, especially for people that already played lots of adventures.

Luckily there is a map and some hints to make your journey easier from time to time and there’s also some kind of information section that will tell you something about the history behind Year Walking, the folklore and the mysterious appearances. It was surprisingly interesting to read all the available information, especially due to the fresh setting that was not already used a hundred times in different games and stories. There’s also a very mysterious journal that requires a username and a password for access and stays a complete secret until you have finished the game at least once.

The visuals and the interesting design of 'Year Walk' are definitely the strongest part of the game, but in combination with an interesting story and the great soundtrack (albeit there’s not that much music, mostly in intense situations) the game's able to create a fantastic amosphere. Out there in a dark forest inhabitated by strange beings that are neither entirely good nor bad there’s a lot of potential for sending chills down your spine.
__________________________________________ 

[h1]Contra[/h1]

Unfortunately the games‘ lenght is from my point of view also the games' biggest downside: your first run will take approximately between two or three hours and as soon as you understand the puzzles and know how to solve them without searching for clues you will be able finish the game quite fast. There’s an achievement that wants you to finish the game in less than 20 minutes and in the end it’s not that particularly hard to get.

Another thing that I would like to mention here are the jumpscares – I simply don’t like them as an element to 'inflict' horror, they feel a bit... cheap. From my point of view the game has a strong atmosphere by itself and does not really need these „SURPRISE: spooky face riiiiiiight in front of the screen‘-moments to scare you. Luckily there are only a few of them.

The last negative point would be the implementation of touchscreen controls. At first I thought that the touchscreen of my Surface Tablet would be enough to play the game (because the game itself was ported from iOS to PC) but unfortunately you need a keyboard to move (and to solve one puzzle). 
__________________________________________ 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

In the end I can say that the game surprised me a lot and the positive qualities of 'Year Walk‘ outweigh the short length by far. Sure, the games‘ charm is mostly created by the interesting visuals and the fresh setting but it succeeds nonetheless in building up a dense and mysterious atmosphere. There are some sparse horror elements – e.g. unexpected jump scares - but overall it’s the fear of what may happen and what lies at the end of your walk that will give you some chills, the story within the story. 

It's definitely an interesting little horror-adventure that may entertain you for two up to three hours. Luckily there's some replayability due to a secret ending. In the end I would rate the game 8 out of 10 points and especially during sales it’s a great little title to grab.
__________________________________________ 

This endorsement approved by [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/trureviews]The Reviewers' Union[/url],
providing better standards for reviews and reviewers.

I really, [i] really [/i] loved this game. It's just one of those games where you think about for hours long after you've finished playing it - the art style is both beautiful and unnerving, and the music is eerie yet simple enough as to be not overstated. The horror in this game doesn't lie in its jumpscares - there are very few, only about 3 if I remember correctly, although they honestly freaked me out considerably - but its overall tone and plot. This game is [i] heavy [/i] on suggestion as well: there are no monsters, except maybe [spoiler] the deer-headed thing [/spoiler], seeing as he's pretty unsettling, and it's implied that [spoiler] you may not be so innocent yourself [/spoiler]. You'll probably need to use a walkthrough at points on your first playthrough, especially if you want the acheivement for completing the game in 20 minutes. Also, don't be fooled by the credits - if you stay until they've finished and complete a small puzzle, you'll unlock a very interesting bonus...
All in all, this game is exactly what a horror game should be - it doesn't try too hard to freak you out, although it will definitely raise a few hairs on the back of your neck; it doesn't have constant jumpscares; it's a very intricately woven story, especially with the use of real Swedish mythology thrown in. 
I just can't state enough how much I really loved this game, and I hope this review helps. xD

28355252.review:
[b]Year Walk[/b] is a beauty. It’s a vague, elusive game, the sort that drops a player in the atmospheric snow with no instructions apart from forward back left right mouse, and says, Go find the Mill. And so we do. 

The art is papery in a palette of rich and pale red-browns and grays, and everything is cladded in snowdrifts. We move through small wintry areas on a sketchy, spidery map, dotted with bleak features: a dead campfire, a rickety fence, a frozen pond, a bit of snow-streaked path. There are secrets to find, and a small encyclopedia describing a few of the Swedish mythic creatures we may encounter along the way. It’s a hushed world, reluctant with its discoveries. 

Some of the puzzles are outright puzzling, and on my first ending - at about 90 minutes, and I’m not all that game-clever, if you’re looking for a measure - I wasn’t sure what had just gone down. But this game isn’t over until you see the words “The End,” which in my case was at the finish of my third cycle - more alert players may finish it in just two. I played without hints, apart from the in-game clue system, and am really glad I did, because when the hidden story is revealed the experience is rich and exciting.

I LOVED THIS ONE, and recommend it highly if you’re mystery-tolerant. 

Later update: I've nominated this one for the 2017 Defies Description Steam award. Yay!

28319787.review: A delightfully dark folk tale adventure based on Norse mythology, Year Walk looks and feels like a disturbing bedtime story for children. The art style is endearingly creepy and original, and creates a very engrossing atmosphere for the story that is deceptively simple but has a lot of depth for those who pay attention. Those who do not, will almost certainly not like this game. Year Walk does no hand holding and requires pen and paper to keep track of clues and puzzle pieces. It is a practice that is all but lost in modern gaming, and will undoubtedly turn off some gamers. For those who pay attention however, the puzzles should not cause any trouble to solve; they "make sense" and are straightforward throughout. Like most children's books, Year Walk is very short and can easily be completed in under 2-3 hours for a first comprehensive walkthrough, with each consecutive run taking no more than 20 minutes (take a look at the achievements if you do not believe me). I wholeheartedly recommend you pick up this gem. After all, "the woods are lovely, dark, and deep..."

28266127.review:
This is a great game, although I recommend getting it on sale because it's so short. As you can see in the achievements section, one of the achievables is a "Year Run," or getting through a full year walk in 20 minutes. Granted, there's almost no way to do that the first time round unless you're using a walkthrough, but it's useful to illustrate how quick the story can be. Without giving too much of the plot away, a full experience of the game requires a minimum of two year walks.

In terms of genre, I'd sooner call this game "dark fantasy" than "horror," as there are only three total jumpscares, even using the most expansive definition: moments that succeed in startling chihuahua-like individuals such as myself. As far as actual scary moments, there's really only one. Still, the game is stylistically horror-tinged throughout. It's not so much a bloodbath as it is blood slowly soaking through cloth. Both have their benefits.

The puzzles are fairly simplistic, but without the use of a walkthrough, the game is still surprisingly difficult, if only because it drops you in the middle of snowy nowhere without holding your hand and pushing you in the right direction. Luckily, there's a happy medium between muddling through it alone and full-on cheating: in-game hints. They're actually really helpful if you get stuck. 

It's sort of like falling asleep partway through a documentary on Swedish folktales and having a sick nightmare about it. Didn't your mother ever tell you not to do lucy while watching PBS?

27869474.review:
'Year Walk' es... es... único. Creo que se podría considerar un concepto puro. No se deja influenciar por nada más que la base jugable de una aventura "point & click" tradicional. Es uno de esos juegos medio-sensoriales que intentan transmitir conceptos complejos mediante una simpleza brillante... y eso tiene mucho mérito.

Coge la mitología sueca (del que personalmente no había sabido nada hasta ahora) y crea una pequeña línea argumental que acoge varios relatos de lo más interesantes. ¿Sabéis de esas pequeñas enciclopedias o registros que hay en algunos juegos donde puedes leer descripciones y pasajes del contexto histórico, personajes y demás? Bien, ¿a que muchos de vosotros ni las lee? Eso es lógicamente porque ninguna de esa información tiene relación directa con la acción del juego.

Pues en 'Year Walk' la tiene. Su "enciclopedia" tiene muy pocas entradas, y aún sin ser necesario, me sorprendí leyéndolo todo con mucho gusto.

Resumiendo: es corto, bello e intenso. Además, me cabreó. Su creador es un cab***, como el logo del juego.

Pero se me quedará en la memoria y eso es lo más significativo de una obra de arte. Muy recomendable.

25954967.review:
This game is an experience.

It may be a dumb thing to say. After all, playing any game is an "experience. But while I can recommend many games for their rich story, challange they provide, interesting gameplay mechanics or simply beacuse they're entertaining, Year Walk is one of few games that I think should be played just to be experienced.

The atmosphere is amazing. Persanally, I took interest in this title because it had "Horror" in it's tags, but it's so much more than that. The world, while not big, feels rich, magical and mysterious. Inclusion of things based on the Swedish folklore in the major reason for that.
Still, I can't say that it lacks in the horror department. It can be unnervingly creepy at times.

Game's art style is just gorgeous to look at and intensifies the tone of the game dramatically.

Gameplay is fairly simple. It focuses on exploration and solving dofferent puzzles, which are not too hard nor too easy. It shouldn't be the problem for any time of gamer.

If this game peaked your interest, you love a good atmosphere, and you like solving brain teasers while traveling alone in the woods filled with strange creatures, then you should give Year Walk a try. You won't regret it.

25896500.review:
Published by: Simogo
Developed by: Simogo
Genre: Puzzle, Indie, Horror
Release Date: 7 March, 2014
Time to complete: 1.5 hours

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
A puzzle game with a twist; Year Walk is a horror interpretation of the Ancient Swedish folklore ‘Årsgång’.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Set in the 19th Century, you venture through the woods full of unsettling creatures and a dark foreboding atmosphere, taking part in a Year Walk. The scenery starts off pleasant enough, a picturesque snowy woodland. As you walk further and further, more secrets unfold and the eerie surroundings become more and more intense (and in some cases, outright disturbing). A lot of navigating and exploration is required to work out the puzzles; there is a map to help with this however, and also hints should you find yourself stuck. The story unravels as you unlock more puzzles, often adding to the mystery rather than solving it. I rather like both puzzle and horror games, and enjoyed the creepy combination of the two in this very well-made folklore rendition. There’s plenty of reading material (especially at the ‘end’, don’t skip the end credits!) which I enjoyed going through.
Though the puzzles were really well formulated in my opinion, my favourite part was piecing everything together in the end and discovering the story myself; seeing all the initially puzzling scenes come together to tell the whole story. I like how subtle the clues were, encouraging me to unlock all the secrets and dig deeper into the background of the story.

[h1]Graphics & Art[/h1]
The game is beautiful, that much can be observed by looking at the store page; it’s set in a dreary yet alluring snowy woodland. Even the disturbing aspects are somewhat beautiful in a twisted way. The art is bright yet dark, pretty yet depraved; a perfect amalgamation of two opposite forces creating something so very captivating.

[h1]Replay Value[/h1]
Being a puzzle game, once you’ve worked out all the clues there is little point playing it again. The entire purpose of Year Walk, or at least in my opinion, is slowly allowing the clues to unfold as you play. 

[h1]Soundtrack[/h1]
The instrumental soundtrack is pleasant to listen to, with unsettling tracks and effects throughout to accentuate certain scenes. 

[h1]Achievements[/h1]
Not all achievements are obtainable by playing the game through (one being ‘Year Run’ which is essentially a speedrun, and fairly impossible to do on the first playthrough). There are guides available to help with the trickier achievements if you are stuck. 

[h1]Difficulty & Challenge[/h1]
The mechanics are very simple, but don’t let that fool you; some puzzles and their corresponding clues can be terribly vague. At times, the clues can be found before you even realise what puzzle they are for. For this reason, I suggest you take note of your surroundings (potentially even writing them down). A lot of the puzzles do seem simplistic, but because of the ambiguity of the clues (and the fact that you often find them before even knowing what to do with them), they seem a lot harder and did leave me somewhat perplexed on a few occasions. 

[h1]Overall Verdict[/h1]
I find that horror games are often lacking in the narrative department, being more about a few jump scares here and there and a few bloodied creatures lurking around the place, rather than venturing into the domain of [i]why[/i] (e.g. sure having a random creature jump out at you as you explore is frightening, but it’s irrelevant to the story). This is where Year Walk stands out from the rest; not only does it have unsettling visuals and audio, it proves that a well-written story is enough to send chills down your spine. Year Walk doesn’t rely on the standard scare-tactics of your average horror game, because it doesn’t have to. 

[h1]Overall Score: 9/10[/h1]

25862931.review:
For the longest time I put off buying Year Walk since the price tag versus the average amount of hours reviewers played tended to scare me away.  I usually like investing in things I know I'll get a good amount of time out of, and I felt that I could just as easily wait for a sale to get something that I'd spend more time on for around the same price. I know this is incredibly moronic tact to take with games, but I've been burned more often than not on shorter "experiences" to come to have that reservation.  

Having bought and completed Year Walk, I can honestly say I wish I pulled the trigger on the game sooner.

The folklore the game is based on is interesting and a bit unsettling, leading to simple, yet effective scares that managed to stick with me.  Wrapped around this is a pretty well done story, that even with accidentally getting spoiled on some of the details, I came away impressed with.  While I wouldn't say the puzzles are anything too special, combined with an atmospheric soundtrack and the game's 2.5D first person presentation, they were enough to get me to want to to keep going.

Admittedly, Year Walk might not be everyone's cup of tea. Regardless, if you're looking for something different, I highly recommend taking a chance on it.

[I]Year Walk[/i] was game I had in my library for quite a long time. I was always sure, that eventually I get to the point of playing it ... Well, I finally reach that point.

Let me say from the get go - this is one [u]BEAUTIFUL[/u] looking, sounding game, with great atmosphere and lore behind it.

There is not much into the mechanics, you walk left-right-forward-backwards, interact with things, but that doesn't matter at all, because story is the meat of this game. You wonder around, doing back and forth to progress, to reach the end, that is maaaaaaaaaaaaybe kinda predictable, but still will leave uncomfortable feeling inside you.

I enjoyed myself a lot, but without proper guide (thanks [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/thenicestguy] Hen City guest [/url]) I would be completely miserable and wouldn't know what to do in preper manor and full sanity levels - I'm really dumb like that with puzzles in game and IRL.

You, Dear Reader should definitely pick this one from your library when you are not sure what to play. 
I'm sure [i]Year Walk[/i] will leave you in awe, and wanting explore more with journal and second ending(!), and maybe to go on a Year Walk by yourself - who knows?
And please do one more thing: Don't expect horror. Just don't. 

[i]Grade:[/i][b] A[/b]

25452574.review:
Year Walk's art style is great, and is the main reason to play it. If all you're looking for is a short game with some creepy visuals, then by all means, play Year Walk. However, don't expect any more than exactly that.

The story is extremely predictable, what little of it there is, and retreads ground that's been stomped to death by other dime a dozen indie horror games. Apart from a few exceptions, the puzzles are patronizingly simplistic and uninspired at best, and needlessly tedious at worst. That tediousness mostly stems from the way the world is constructed, making it difficult to remember where to find anything that isn't a major landmark. I understand that the authors wanted to evoke a "lost in the woods" feeling, but moving between screens very quickly became dull rather than creepy.

I don't recommend this game unless you don't mind a surface level, derivative experience.

25427284.review:
[h1]Страшная сказка из шведского леса[/h1]

У каждой страны есть свои легенды и обычаи, которые уходят корнями в историю народа. Благодаря игре Year Walk, мы можем прикоснуться к шведскому фольклору, который мастерски подан игроку. Как в настоящей сказке мы встретимся с несколькими потусторонними существа. Пока мы не выполним их поручения или не разгадаем загадки, дальше дороги не будет. 
Пройти игру стоит по нескольким причинам: 

Плюсы

[list]
   [*][u]Ламповая атмосфера[/u]. Где с первых минут игрок погружается в предновогоднюю сказку, где творится настоящее волшебство.  
   [*]Игра [u]пугает[/u] в самые неожиданные моменты. 
   [*][u]Две концовки[/u]. Не смотря на то, что игру можно пройти за пару часов, разработчики предусмотрели 2 концовки - хорошую и плохую. 
   [*][u]Замечательный саундтрек[/u], который создает нужное настроение и даже рассказывает нам чуть больше о каждом персонаже. За прекрасно выполненную работу можно сказать спасибо композитору Daniel Olsén. 
[/list]

Минусы

[list]
   [*]Игра [u]короткая[/u]. Если посмотреть ачивки, то разработчики предполагают, что Year Walk можно пройти за 20 минут, конечно, если знать, куда идти. 
[/list]

Прежде, чем начинать игру, обязательно прочтите энциклопедию. Она сможет настроить вас на нужный лад и понять подоплеку происходящего. 

Если вам понравилась [u]Fran Bow[/u], то Year Walk определенно для вас.

Огромное спасибо, что дочитали мой обзор до конца ♡♡♡

25355759.review:
Ho preso questo gioco in offerta, per fortuna, perché effettivamente non vale più di 1,50 euro.
Questa è l'ultima volta che cado nella tentazione di provare un gioco pensato per dispositivi mobili, nel caso specifico per IOS. Sono cascato nella trappola mediatica. Year Walk ha valutazioni altissime in giro sul web e le recensioni non risparmiano lodi; in particolare sottolineano gli aspetti artistici del titolo. Beh, in quanto amministratore di un sito dedicato all'arte videoludica, non potevo esimermi dal provarlo, vista anche la cifra ridicola necessaria.

Il primo impatto è positivo. L'estetica è curata e l'immagine leggermente disturbata, l'effetto neve e i colori tenui creano una certa atmosfera. Il comparto sonoro fatto di venti, sospiri e piccoli ma suggestivi temi di carillon risulta appropriato. Si apprezza anche la documentazione scritta della storia e delle varie entità soprannaturali.
Intriganti anche alcuni momenti di puro horror, con rare punte di tensione e un paio di jump scare. L'iconografia degli esseri sovrannaturali è suggestiva ed è tratta dal folklore svedese, la nazionalità degli sviluppatori.

Però contemporaneamente si manifestano molti limiti, che alla lunga diluiscono e vanificano questi aspetti positivi. 
E' possibile muoversi solo a destra e sinistra con i tasti freccia, anche se guardiamo sempre verso il fondo dello schermo, una meccanica fatta ad hoc per il touch screen. Si passa da una scena all'altra andando in avanti o indietro in corrispondenza di taluni passaggi segnati sulla mappa di gioco. In sostanza è come se non ci muovessimo, ma sfogliassimo delle pagine, proprio come faremmo con un touch screen. Il mondo di gioco è piccolissimo, un numero ridottissimo di isolotti che ci ritroveremo ad esplorare più e più volte, con pochissime occasioni di interazione; impossibile non farsi prendere dalla noia dopo un po'. 

A parte le premesse iniziali contenute nei documenti in nostro possesso e nel filmato iniziale in cui parliamo con la nostra amata, per il resto lo sviluppo della storia è inesistente! Il finale, così tanto decantato dalle riviste e dagli entusiati, è di una banalità più unica che rara. Se cercate emozioni,  a parte un paio di jump scare, avete scelto il titolo sbagliato!

Il gioco è centrato unicamente sulla risoluzione di enigmi e puzzle! Sostanzialmente, al di là del maquillage costruitogli attorno con qualche cenno superficiale di trama, con un'estetica di facciata e una patinata atmosfera horror, il gioco si riduce ad un passatempo enigmistico!
I puzzle e gli enigmi sono abbastanza astrusi, ma con pazienza possono essere risolti, a patto di non annoiarsi come il sottoscritto, che nei videogiochi cerca tutt'altro, per il resto preferisce la Settimana Enigmistica! Motivo per cui dopo la prima ora di gioco, preso dalla noia e dal disinteresse più totale, ho fatto uso di un walkthrough per arrivare diritto fino alla fine e valutare per intero il titolo. 

Il vero problema è che l'interattività è praticamente nulla, caratteristica tipica dei giochi casual per dispositivi mobili. Gli oggetti con cui è possibile interagire sono pochissimi. E il modo in cui si interagisce è primitivo. Cosa aspettarsi d'altronde da un gioco per cellulari in cui tutto si riduce a far scivolare il dito sul touch screen? Inoltre non esistono scelte, bivi, dialoghi a scelta multipla, niente di niente. Solo noiosissimi enigmi!
In più le idee sono trite e ritrite, viste mille volte in tanti giochi o film o fumetti; il che dimostra come le recensioni in giro per il web siano falsate ed edulcorate, poichè pretendono che il gioco sia fortemente originale, innovativo, addirittura epocale, regalandogli votazioni dal 9 in su!
Qualcuno dirà che bisogna giudicare in base alle ridotte capacità tecniche dei dispositivi mobili! Ma anche in questo caso Year Walk fa una figura canina, si salva solo per l'estetica. Infatti come è noto sui dispositivi mobili è possibile giocare a tante storiche avventure grafiche degli anni '70, '80 e '90 e molte di esse risultano ben più interattive, intriganti, emozionanti e divertenti!

Ho scritto la recensione di Year Walk perché volevo mettere a nudo la sua vera natura da puzzle game per telefonino e l'assoluta inaffidabilità delle recensioni in giro sul web. E' un titolo adatto a giocatori casual non più giovanissimi, che non hanno molta esperienza e dimestichezza con il mondo videoludico, in cui per fortuna non mancano ben altri titoli di pregevole fattura densi di arte, emozioni e contenuti. 

Effettivamente questo tipo di pubblico può trovare interessante gli enigmi di Year Walk, contornati da un plot minimale, confezionati con un'estetica accattivante e un minimo di atmosfera e con il bonus di qualche punta orrorifica e di tensione. In effeti svetta rispetto ad altri prodotti casual, ma nulla di più. Spacciarlo come gioco per PC o per console, esiste anche la versione per WII, mi sembra inappropriato.

VOTO: 68/100

http://steamcommunity.com/groups/vgart

24812247.review:
Ein schönes, aber kurzes Adventure mit Rätseleinlagen.

Wer eine Wintergeschichte aus Skandinavien nacherleben möchte, der ist hier genau richtig.
Grafikstil, Sound und Gameplay geben eine interessante Mischung ab und heben sich klar vom Standard ab.
Es ist zwar nichts besonderes, aber mal was anderes, und vor allem interessant gemacht.
Nach ein paar Minuten hat man sich an die Steuerung gewöhnt.
Wer ohne Hilfe spielen will, der muss zwingend alles unterwegs mitmalen und aufschreiben.
Dann alles wird irgendwo benötigt.
Seien es Symbole oder Zahlen in der richtigen Reihenfolge, oder halt was anderes.
Nach dem ersten Durchgang kommt der Abspann, nach dem es jedoch noch weiter geht!
Man startet dann noch einmal bei seiner Hütte udn versucht dann die Holzkiste zu öffnen, die man gleich zu Beginn sieht.
Der Weg zu ist, sich auf der Karte die genannten Stellen näher anzuschauen udn die so erhaltenen Daten als Login für das Archiv zu nutzen. Dort gibt es dann weitere Infos zu suchen, die dann auf die Kombination hinweisen. 
Jedenfalls ist erst dann das Spiel vorbei und man hat das eigentliche Ende "zum Guten hin" korrigiert.
Ich wünsche euch viel Spaß damit, denn es ist unbedingt zu empfehlen.
Wer das Spiel in einem Bundle bekommen hat, sollte es auch mal spielen, auch wenn er eigentlich nicht solche Spiele bevorzugt.
Es ist halt recht kurz, vor allem, wenn man nicht alle Rätsel selbst herausfinden will und den Fokus mehr auf Story setzt.
Praktisch kann man das Spiel in 20 Minuten durchrennen, es gibt sogar ein Abzeichen dafür.
Wer sich alles selber erarbeiten will, der benötigt aber sicher auch mal schnell 3 Stunden dafür.
Kommt drauf an, wie gut seine Aufzeichnungen sind und wie gut man durch den Wald findet.

Wertung:  7,5 / 10

24757083.review:
[h1]Year Walk[/h1]

This review was last edited when I had completed the game

[h1]Short Review[/h1]

A very original, highly stylised 2/2.5D adventure/puzzle game with excellent puzzles. Often I had only a vague idea about what was actually going on but somehow that was all part of its charm. Highly recommended.

[h1]Long Review[/h1]

This is certainly one of the most unusual games I've played in a long time. Essential it's a 2.5D adventure game with puzzles & an interesting if abstract storyline. The game is played in relatively limited area of forested Scandinavia but don't let the limited area put you off. The scenery is full of detail with, often abstract, clues.

The 2.5D gameplay is unique in my experience. You move smoothly to the left and right but depth movement is a sudden rush that moves you between 2D sections. There are prompts on the top and bottom of the screen in the form of arrows that indicate when forwards or backwards movement is possible. There is a map that can be brought up at any time which shows the links between the 2D sections as well as prominent features in the landscape.

There is no hand holding. You are told to use WASD keys and the mouse button to interact and then you're on your own. In fact you're on your own to the point that after the initial intro I really hadn't a clue what I was supposed to do so it was a case of wandering around exploring intially until slowly but surely after visiting places several times the penny dropped on what the puzzles actualyl were.

One of the things I liked about the game is that I often found it more difficult figuring out what the puzzles were than actually solving them.

Whilst I didn't actually find the game outright scarey (with a couple of exceptions when things flashed unexpectedly on the screen) I always had a feel of unease playing it. The fear of the unknown, the strange encounters and the eerie music fed into this.

I certainly recommend reading the integrated Encyclopedia before/whilst playing as it explains what the game is about. It is a good, interesting read.

The game progress saves each time you quit.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
[*]Beautiful, stylised graphics
[*]Well thought out puzzles
[*]Hint system
[/list]
[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*]I found it pretty difficult
[*]The control to interact with objects is pretty tricky
[*]Sometimes the hint system just told me stuff I already knew but not what I needed to know
[/list]
[h1]Marks Out Of 5[/h1]

5) Must have - stop whatever you're playing now and play this
[h1]4) Worth the asking price and considering as your next purchase[/h1]
3) Maybe purchase if you're stuck for choosing your next game or mildly discounted
2) Only purchase if it is heavily discounted
1) Not worth getting even if given away free

[h1]Where I got the game from[/h1]

Bought at [url=https://www.bundlestars.com/en/] Bundle Stars [/url] as part of the All Stars 6 Bundle

[h1]Platform Played On[/h1]

Intel Pentium G3258 Anniversary Edition, 8Gb RAM, Palit GTX 750, Windows 10, EasyAcc Mouse & Steelseries MERC keyboard. 

[h1]My best guess for a  PEGI Rating [/h1]

12: There are some pretty dark parts to the storyline. [url=http://www.pegi.info/en/index/id/33/] PEGI Ratings [/url]

24325099.review:
Very engaging, albeit short experience. 

Year Walk is not really a horror game, despite the tags, although the ambience is creepy and there are a few scares, it's not too vicious. It's more of a puzzle game, with a very interesting story, which is only mostly revealed at the end of the game. Even then, it leaves room for interpretation.

The puzzles are fun, they never left me thinking "that was stupidly illogical", nor "that was stupidly easy", like many puzzle games do, on occasion. And they manage to do this while being to some degree abstract, with few hints, which is admirable.

The graphics are fantastic, in my opinion: beautiful art style, clean, and clear.

Sound design is good, one puzzle relies entirely on sound, and is challenging but fair, so no complaints in this department.

Story, like I said, I enjoyed it very much, open to interpretation, yet I wasn't left feeling cheated out of a satisfying end.

The game also includes nordic folklore, which I found very interesting.

The game is quite short, so you may want to pick it up on sale if you are averse to games with few hours in them.

All in all, Year Walk is, in my opinion, a great game, deserving of the (currently) 87 metacritic score, as well as the 90%+ positive reviews.

24282892.review:
I just finished my very first Year Walk and it was absolutely fantastic.

Concept: A year walk was a Swedish ritual that, if completed, could tell the future. You decide to embark on a year walk.
Replay Worthy?: Absolutely; in fact, replaying the game is pretty much required. Your first year walk's end is NOT the end of the game.
Horror Factor: In my first walk there was only one jump scare. The horror comes from the lore surrounding the creatures and the stark, eerie beauty of the woods you're in.
Music: Beautiful soundtrack that was haunting and fit well with the story.
Characters: There aren't many but the characters that did appear were fantastic.
Art: It was oddly beautiful and fit well with the story.
Puzzles: Difficult to say the least, but they were fun.

Only thing I didn't like was how short my first walk was; I was expecting it to be ~4-6 hours.

All in all, wonderful game. I might update this review when after I've replayed it a few times but so far I'm giving it a 96/100.

24266955.review:
Incroyable.

Year walk fait partie de ces jeux "expérience" comme l'était le premier portal, vous le prenez, vous le finissez d'un seul trait, et vous découvrez qu'il y a tellement derrière.

Pour faire simple, Year Walk est un jeu d'exploration / horreur dans lequel vous allez partir faire un year walk (comme c'est bien fait :p), une vieille croyance scandinave que vous aurez l'occasion de découvrir, au même titre qu'une partie de sa mythologie.

Au début on croirait à un petit jeu indé basique, avec son style qui, même s'il a du charme, n'a rien de spécialement magnifique.

Et pourtant, une fois lancé, on découvre le jeu: il y a une carte (oui ça paraît con mais ça a son intérêt ici), un système de conseils pour nous aider lorsque l'on est coincé (il est progressif, le dernier étant généralement un spoil pur et simple de ce qu'il faut faire), on peut regarder le "bestiaire" qui est un encyclopédie regroupant des... personnages ? mythiques du folklore scandinave et le jeu nous happe pendant une demi heure à une heure (j'y reviendrais).

Une fois le jeu fini, on est conquis. Et pourtant le jeu ne fait que commencer car il vous faudra maintenant résoudre les mystères qui entourent votre personnage. Et c'est reparti pour une autre demi heure (peut-être même plus) d'enquête cette fois ci, toujours dans une ambiance oppressante à souhait.

Néanmoins, si vous êtes arrivés jusqu'ici, peut-être êtes vous indécis. Et c'est normal au vu de la durée de vie que j'ai citée. Je conseille donc de le prendre en promo, même si ce jeu fait partie de mon top 5 car 5€ pour 1h-1h30 de jeu cela fait relativement cher.





En résumé: Super jeu avec une grosse ambiance et un univers à couper le souffle, mais une durée de vie limitée qui oblige presque à l'acheter en promo afin de ne pas avoir le sentiment amer de s'être fait pigeonner. Attention néanmoins à bien parler anglais au risque de vivre une longue heure de solitude.

24221463.review: I played this game on my friends iPad and then bought it on steam because it looked interesting. I beat it twice and have gotten into the lore quite a bit. But on New Year's Eve of 2015 (this is a true story btw) I had a dream about this game in the perspective of the character you play as, but when I woke up it was still dark, I couldn't move (sleep paralasis) and I was hallucinating what looked like theoutline of the grim. Was absolutely terrifying but then everything went back to normal in what seemed like 30 minutes. Overall, great game 10/10 IGN would hallucinate again.

There isn't much else to be said about Year Walk that hasn't been said already. I'm not the point 'n' click type and I'm not sure what pulled me toward this game but it scared me in all the good ways and more importantly its story fascinated me. After my first playthrough I was genuinely interested in learning about the lore of Year Walking or "Årsgång" and I think a lot of horror games are missing that element of everlasting wonder, y'know? Those haunting moments that never really let go and have you jumping at your shadow. The game itself isn't very long, with a typical playthrough lasting 45mins-1hour, but you'll find yourself mesmerized by the ending and the ***SPOILER*** [spoiler]  journal you unlock which sheds light on the present day researcher looking into the mystery of year walking [/spoiler]

My only gripe with this game is that its short!

+atmosphere
+story
-length

23815458.review:
There's a kind of game that doesn't repeat itself.
It's not bloated with grinding, nor trying to incentivize the player with microachievements and level-ups. It doesn't stroke your space-marine ego, and it doesn't boast lifelike graphics and physics. No, this game just wants to tell you a story and make you feel something.

This is why I love Year Walk. It's atmospheric, clever, stylized, and steeped in folklore.

You are a man attempting a Year Walk--a nighttime stroll through a supernatural forest to win a prophetic vision. It plays like a point-and-click minus the tedioum. There is no inventory, no dialogue trees, no rapid-fire click spaming to find objects of interest. Just exploration and a wealth of bite-sized puzzles, 

On three occasions, I've sat friends down to play the entire game while I watched over their shoulders. They were all spellbound. I say with certainty that Year Walk is worth your time.

23814628.review:
This game is a lovely point-and-click puzzle horror game. For $5 it's more than worth it, and playing it again was very nostalgic. The developers went for a choice that favors symbolism over action, so if that isn't your thing, don't pick this up. It's very artsy, and there are a bunch of secrets hidden after you beat it for the first time, so it has a decent amount of replay value.

10/10 Flawless

23677807.review: Beautiful. Why complain about a beautiful game for 6 dollars?

23671207.review:
Year Walk is a game that I first purchased about a month after it's release here on Steam, over two years ago. I mainly just wanted a quick horror fix, and what I got was a lot more. This game focuses on the very obscure ancient Swedish tradition of Årsgång, or Year Walking. After playing this game, I was awestruck by not only the way the story was presented, but also by the amazing visuals, and how even though there was certainly horror elements in the game, I felt completely comfortable. 

Upon completing this game, I felt like I needed to know more about this tradition that was Årsgång. This feeling sent me on a two year journey through Swedish sources and 20 year old dead internet forums that helped me conclude a whole blog and thesis on this subject. Never has a game compelled me so strongly to find out more, and to know all I can possibly know, and in April of this year, I had done it. I had found out all there was to know about this once obscure tradition that now found itself as common knowledge.

This is why I am asking everybody who could be reading this to BUY THIS GAME. You will be intrigued, terrified, curious, excited, mystified, and much more over this 2 or so hour journey, maybe three if you read the excellent encyclopedia. I've played this game 5 times now at different speeds and settings, just to make sure I found every little thing in this game. Now that I have, I must say it was completely worth it, and I'm sure I'll be going back to it again soon. Some people may find this game boring, and I understand that, it's not necessarily for everybody out there, but please just try it. This game is $6.00 (£4.10), when it should easily go for twice that price. if I had to give this game some sort of overall rating, it must be a 10/10. I feel ridiculous giving a rating out to a game that has changed the way I see things so much but I feel it's justified. Just play it.

23488985.review:
So I learned this pretty fact about Christian churches in Sweden, you can read it in the compendium in-game as well:

[spoiler] When a church was built in midieval times, an animal was sometimes buried alive under the floors - most commonly goats since these were comparatively cheap. There have also been stories of criminals being buried alive as punishment. In other versions the criminal's heart was cut out and placed inside an animal carcass that was sacrificed.	[/spoiler]

If you are into creepy folklore, like eerie stories and atmospheric games with a unique art style, this is for you.

23287584.review: Year Walk has a way of leaving one wishing for more of the story, and wondering where the lines between game and academia lay. It is one of few games where following the clues after your first playthrough leads to larger revelations of the story, rather than bells and whistles. But in a true twist, leaving the world of the game to do your own research leads to a surprising discovery. Though similar to Never Alone in its ability to extend cultural lore to a wider audience, Year Walk is not built with the purpose of accurate celebration of ancient Scandanavian folklore. However, it is a lovely game full of lonely visuals that harken to a time when people believed in the things that go bump in the night. If you enjoy folklore and visual artistry, this game is worth the few hours of your time it will take to complete.
